falstad
Class RangeSet

java.lang.Object
  falstad.RangeSet

public class RangeSet
extends java.lang.Object

Class stores a set of ranges, i.e., intervals. Its single current user is the Maze class. Note: remove and intersect operate on a set of elements, however there is no method to add more than a single element to the set as the set method removes all previous elements from the set. This only way to increase the cardinality is to split an existing interval into two by way of the remove method. This implies that ranges are disjoint and sorted in increasing order. This code is refactored code from Maze.java by Paul Falstad, www.falstad.com, Copyright (C) 1998, all rights reserved Paul Falstad granted permission to modify and use code for teaching purposes. Refactored by Peter Kemper

Method Detail

isEmpty

public boolean isEmpty()
Tells if the set is empty.

Returns:
true if the set is empty, false otherwise

set

public void set(int mn,
                int mx)
Clears the set and fills it with a single new element as specified

Parameters:
mn - minimum value for new element
mx - maximum value for new element

remove

public void remove(int fx,
                   int tx)
Removes interval [fx,tx] from existing set such that none of its elements intersects with it anymore. Existing intervals are reduced if they intersect, split into two or fully removed if they are contained in [fx,tx]

Parameters:
fx - is the lower bound of the interval
tx - is the upper bound of the interval

intersect

public boolean intersect(java.awt.Point p)
Tells if there is at least one interval that intersects with [p.x,p.y]. It modifies attributes of p in case of an intersection. A point is used as a quick hack to communicate two integers and being able to return modified values in a boolean method.

Parameters:
p - describes interval [p.x,p.y], its entries are modified to represent the intersection if there is one
Returns:
true if there is an intersection, false otherwise
